summary: This document contains official correspondence from the U.S. Virgin Islands Department of Justice to Jeffrey Epstein, notifying him of strict travel reporting requirements as a registered sex offender. It includes a notification form and a follow-up letter from the Moroccan Ministry of the Interior confirming Epstein's travel to Morocco in April 2019. The document shows authorities monitoring Epstein's international movements.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Registered Sex Offender / Recipient of Notification
persons.context: The primary subject of the travel notification requirements as a registered sex offender in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The Moroccan document confirms his travel to Morocco in April 2019.

persons.name: Carol Thomas-Jacobs
persons.context: Signed the March 14, 2019 letter from the U.S. Virgin Islands Department of Justice to Jeffrey Epstein outlining the new travel compliance conditions.

persons.name: Youssef Chami
persons.role: Director General for National Security / Chief of Cabinet
persons.context: Signed the Moroccan Ministry of the Interior document confirming Jeffrey Epstein's border entries and exits in Morocco in April 2019.

connections.description: Thomas-Jacobs, as Acting Attorney General, issued official legal notification to Epstein regarding his travel reporting obligations as a sex offender.
Chami, as a Moroccan security official, responded to a U.S. request for information by confirming Epstein's travel movements through Morocco.

events.title: USVI DOJ Issues Strict Travel Notification to Epstein
events.description: The U.S. Virgin Islands Department of Justice sends a formal letter to Jeffrey Epstein outlining new, stricter conditions for reporting his travel as a registered sex offender, revoking previous provisions.

events.title: Epstein Travels to Morocco
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein enters and exits Morocco via Marrakech-Menara Airport, as confirmed by Moroccan authorities in response to a U.S. information request.

events.title: Morocco Confirms Epstein's Travel
events.description: The Moroccan Ministry of the Interior's General Directorate for National Security responds to a May 20, 2019 U.S. request, confirming Epstein's border passages in April 2019.

locations: 6100 Red Hook, Suite B3, St. Thomas, VI 00802-1348 (Epstein's address)
keyFacts: In March 2019, the U.S. Virgin Islands Department of Justice revoked previous travel notification provisions for Jeffrey Epstein and imposed stricter in-person reporting requirements for both domestic and international travel.

Epstein was required to provide detailed itinerary information including destination, dates, arrival/departure points, address/contact, and purpose of travel at least 21 days before any international trip.
Moroccan authorities confirmed that Jeffrey Epstein entered and exited Morocco on April 25, 2019, through Marrakech-Menara Airport using passport #566672615.
The documents show coordination between U.S. authorities (likely consular/diplomatic security) and Moroccan law enforcement to monitor Epstein's international movements as a registered sex offender.

Failure to comply with the Virgin Islands travel reporting requirements could result in prosecution under both territorial law (fines and imprisonment) and federal law (up to 10 years imprisonment under 18 U.S.C. ยง2250).
